user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemGive_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemGive_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    /*
     * Note there is a possibility that another thread is concurrently taking this sem,
     * and has just checked the current_value but not yet inside the cond_wait call.
     *
     * To address this possibility - the lock must be taken here.  This is unfortunate
     * as it means there may be a task switch when _giving_ a binary semaphore.  But the
     * alternative of having a BinSemGive not wake up the other thread is a bigger issue.
     *
     * Counting sems do not suffer from this, as there is a native POSIX mechanism for those.
     *
     * Note: This lock should be readily available, with only minimal delay if any.
     * If a long delay occurs here, it means something is fundamentally wrong.
     */

    /* Lock the mutex ( not the table! ) */
    if (OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(&sem->id) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /* Binary semaphores are always set as "1" when given */
    sem->current_value = 1;

    /* unblock one thread that is waiting on this sem */
    pthread_cond_signal(&(sem->cv));

    pthread_mutex_unlock(&(sem->id));

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BinSemGive_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_bin_sem_table[OS_MAX_BIN_SEMAPHORES]
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
int32 OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(pthread_mutex_t *mut)
{
    struct timespec timeout;

    if (clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    timeout.tv_sec += OS_POSIX_BINSEM_MAX_WAIT_SECONDS;

    if (pthread_mutex_timedlock(mut, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t       id;
    pthread_cond_t        cv;
    volatile sig_atomic_t flush_request;
    volatile sig_atomic_t current_value;
} OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_SEM_FAILURE (-6)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No for statements are present in the supplied function or in the provided related code snippets/macros. MISRA C:2023 Rule 14.2 concerns the well-formedness of for loops (clauses, loop counter usage, side-effects, etc.). A search of the target function, the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro expansion, the OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex implementation, and the shown type/constant definitions reveals no occurrence of the keyword "for" and no macro expansions that would introduce a for loop. Therefore there are no code fragments relevant to Rule 14.2 to investigate in the supplied code. If there are other source files or functions (not provided here) that contain for loops called from this code, those files should be examined separately for compliance with Rule 14.2.
